title: How to Clean a Faux Leather Jacket

steps.headline: Remove any crusty spots.
steps.description: Before you spot clean your faux leather jacket, carefully go over the fabric to check for dried on spills, such as old food. Gently flake off the residue and wipe the spot with a soft cloth.

steps.headline: Mix mild laundry detergent into warm water.
steps.description: Measure out about a tablespoon (15 milliliters) and pour it into a small bowl of water. Gently stir the water to distribute the soap. If you’re going to purchase a new detergent, try one formulated for delicates. You can also try a commercial faux leather cleaner.

steps.headline: Dampen a soft cloth.
steps.description: Dip a clean cloth into the soapy water to wet it. Wring out the excess water so that your cloth is barely damp. It’s easier to apply more water than it is to remove excess, so wring out as much water as possible.

steps.headline: Wipe down your jacket.
steps.description: Run the damp cloth over your jacket, paying careful attention to scuffs and dirty spots. Rewet your cloth in the soapy water as needed. For best results, spend additional time cleaning spots that suffered spills, dirt, or grime.

steps.headline: Use a clean, damp cloth to remove the excess soap.
steps.description: Wet a fresh cloth and wring out the excess water. Run the damp cloth over your jacket, repeating until no soap remains. Rinse out your cloth between passes over the jacket. If the soap is left on the faux leather jacket, it can cause the jacket to crack and stiffen.

steps.headline: Dry any remaining wetness with a soft cloth.
steps.description: Follow the wet cloth with a clean, dry cloth. Because you’re using little water, you should be able to get it dry with your cloth. If it remains damp, allow the jacket to air dry. Do not try to speed the drying process by putting the jacket in a dryer or trying to use a hair dryer to dry your jacket. Heat will ruin your faux leather jacket.

steps.headline: Apply a conditioner to your jacket.
steps.description: A conditioner will help you keep your jacket from getting too dry, which can cause cracking. Cleaning your jacket can dry it out, so it’s important that you end the process with a conditioner. You can use a commercial product to condition your jacket, or you can polish it with olive oil by dripping a few drops of oil onto a cloth and then applying the oil to your jacket. While faux leather is different from regular leather, you still need to condition it.

steps.headline: Check the tag on your faux leather jacket.
steps.description: Faux leather can come with different care concerns depending on how it’s made and how much of the garment is comprised of faux leather. Before you put your jacket in the washing machine, make sure that the care instructions list it as an option. Recently produced faux leather clothing is commonly marked as machine washable. Do not dry clean your faux leather jacket unless the tag explicitly says to do so. Dry cleaning chemicals dry out faux leather and lead to cracking, stiffness, and discoloration.

steps.headline: Turn your jacket inside out and place it in a mesh garment bag.
steps.description: Protect the look of your jacket by washing it inside out in a laundry bag meant for delicates. If you can’t find a mesh garment bag, try washing your jacket in a pillowcase. Be sure to tie off your pillowcase with a hair elastic or by tying the ends of the pillowcase opening into a knot.

steps.headline: Choose the delicate cycle with low spin.
steps.description: Unless the tag recommends another setting, set your washing machine to wash your jacket on its gentlest cycle using cold water.

steps.headline: Allow your jacket to air dry.
steps.description: Faux leather is easily damaged by heat, so lay out your jacket to let it air dry. You can also try line drying your jacket as long as you evenly distribute it on the hanger so that it doesn’t stretch. If you try to use heat to dry your jacket, it will ruin both the jacket and your dryer. If you are hanging your jacket, make sure that the hanger does not press into the jacket where it isn’t supposed to. The hanger placement should line up with the natural seams of the jacket.

steps.headline: Use a cool iron if needed to remove wrinkles.
steps.description: Place a towel over your faux leather jacket and carefully press the wrinkles with a cool iron. Do not allow the iron to sit on the towel, and make sure that the metal never comes in contact with the jacket. You can also steam your leather jacket to remove wrinkles. Never apply heat to a faux leather jacket.

steps.headline: Sprinkle baking soda inside your jacket.
steps.description: Baking soda absorbs and neutralizes smells without damaging the fabric. Use a liberal amount of baking soda so that most of the inner lining makes contact with it. Don’t forget to put baking soda inside the sleeves.

steps.headline: Place your jacket in an area it will remain undisturbed.
steps.description: Choose an area away from pets and children, such as the center of a table. Lay out your jacket flat so that the baking soda stays in place. Pets and children can become ill if they find and ingest the baking soda.

steps.headline: Allow your jacket to sit overnight.
steps.description: The baking soda needs time to absorb the smell, so leave it undisturbed for at least 8 hours.

steps.headline: Vacuum away the baking soda.
steps.description: Use a small nozzle attachment or a hand held vacuum to remove the baking soda from the jacket, including inside the sleeves. Shake it out and repeat if you see any baking soda fall from the jacket.

steps.headline: Smell your jacket.
steps.description: The bad smell should be gone from your jacket lining. Repeat the process if the smell remains.
